Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Manipulation of Suspended Microparticles via Localized Fluid Boundary Dynamics: Modeling, Simulation, and Experiments

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance a novel, biologically inspired method for the manipulation of solid particles suspended in fluids on a microscopic scale through complementary theoretical, computational, and experimental research. A comprehensive mathematical framework will be developed for describing the control of fluid flows at low Reynolds number through localized cyclic boundary deformations using concepts from differential geometry and dynamical systems theory. A high-fidelity numerical approach will be developed for simulating such problems using a viscous vortex particle method. A pair of experimental platforms on contrasting physical scales will be constructed, each comprising a system of reconfigurable resonant probes mimicking cilia observed in nature, and extensive data will be collected to calibrate both theoretical and computational models. Algorithmic methods for separating and sorting particles, and for tailoring the spatial trajectories of individual particles, will be devised and demonstrated experimentally.

The project focuses on developing and demonstrating a novel technique for separating and manipulating fragile microscopic objects immersed in fluids, which has a growing list of applications ranging from the mechanical testing of macromolecules like DNA to the assisted fertilization of human ova with immotile sperm to the sustained excitation of fluid-borne abrasive particles for the precision machining of brittle surfaces. Models will be developed to predict the trajectories of particles in fluids containing multiple vortex fields. These vortex fields will be produced experimentally using oscillating fibers. A pair of experimental platforms with millimeter and micrometer (1/1000 of a millimeter) physical scales will be constructed. For each platform, a system of reconfigurable resonant probes will be used to generate steady vortex fields in particle-bearing fluids. The smallest probes will mimic the microscopic oscillating cilia observed in nature. Data will be collected to validate the theoretical and computational predictive models. This project will not only engender integrated advancements in applied mathematics, computational science, and engineering, but will also shed light on the physics underlying a physiological design present in protozoa and humans alike. The micromanipulation method to be developed represents an improvement over alternative technologies in simplicity, portability, and cost. The PIs' plan for developing this method incorporates a multi-institutional collaboration involving the directed mentoring of at least one postdoctoral researcher, at least two PhD students, and a number of undergraduates (with a deliberate eye toward promoting diversity), the curricular expansion of two cross-disciplinary graduate courses and two undergraduate courses at the PIs' universities, and outreach to biology students at a third university and to high school students in an ethnically diverse area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When a cylindrical body vibrates from side to side in a viscous fluid within a certain range of cylinder sizes, vibrational frequencies, and fluid viscosities, a distinctive pattern of flow is established in each fluid plane perpendicular to the cylinder. Superposed with the vibration of the fluid is a slower streaming flow that persistently circulates the fluid near the cylinder in a conveyor-belt fashion. The physical regime in which this occurs includes that of many ciliated microorganisms, and streaming flows driven by cilia provide such organisms with the basis for locomotion and for the capture of nutrient particles. Under some physical circumstances, the paths of fluid particles adjacent to a vibrating cylinder will correspond, in each plane perpendicular to the cylinder, to concentric closed loops that comprise “streaming cells”. When a solid particle is placed anywhere within such a cell, it will spiral toward the center of the cell by gradually veering inward as it’s advected by the streaming flow. This phenomenon suggests a novel approach to manipulating solid particles suspended in a viscous fluid in a laboratory setting. By vibrating one or more artificial cilia in such a fluid, particles can be collected at prescribed physical locations, and by altering the nature of the ciliary motion over time, collected particles can be transported and released in a controlled way. This approach promises advantages over existing alternatives when dealing with fragile particles (like biological cells) that might be damaged by direct contact with solid manipulators or when dealing with large numbers of particles in parallel.

This goal of this project was to lay the groundwork for technology of this kind by verifying that the essential physics could be reproduced in an engineered setting and by illuminating these physics, through mathematical and computational modeling in addition to physical experiments, to inform the future development of algorithmic methods for particle manipulation using artificial cilia. An experimental apparatus was constructed to enable controlled streaming flows to be established in water adjacent to a millimeter-scale piezoelectrically vibrated probe and to allow for the optical tracking of micrometer-scale glass beads suspended in the water. At the same time, a high-fidelity computational model for the flow around such a probe, and for the dynamics of particles suspended in the flow, was developed. Qualitative agreement was documented between particle trajectories observed in the laboratory and those predicted in simulations. A detailed analysis was undertaken concerning the forces driving particles toward the centers of streaming cells in the computational model and a qualitative explanation for particle accumulation was developed. The validity of certain reduced-order models for the fluid flow within multi-probe systems, and for the corresponding particle dynamics, was also explored and a particular simplified model was used to validate a method for transporting particles among trapping points in the flow surrounding a pair of probes by manipulating the appearance and disappearance of such trapping points as a result of parametric changes in the excitation of the probes.
